Trading one set of problems for another is not progress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Hon. Frank Pallone"> Thank you, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">I thank the gentleman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We now conclude with Members' opening statements. The Chair would like to remind Members that, pursuant to committee rules, all Members' openings statements will be made part of the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We want to thank all of our witnesses for being here today and taking the time to testify before the subcommittee. Today's witnesses will have the opportunity to give opening statements followed by a round of questions from Members. So we will just begin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">First, I would like to recognize Mr. Timothy Columbus, general counsel, Society of Gasoline Marketers of America and the National Association of Convenience Stores.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Sir, you have 5 minutes. Your full testimony is in the record, and you are now recognized.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF R. TIMOTHY COLUMBUS</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="R. TIMOTHY COLUMBUS"> STATEMENTS OF R. TIMOTHY COLUMBUS, COUNSEL, NATIONAL GASOLINE MARKETERS OF AMERICA; EMILY SKOR, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, GROWTH ENERGY; DAN NICHOLSON, VICE PRESIDENT OF GLOBAL PROPULSION SYSTEMS, GENERAL MOTORS, ON BEHALF OF THE UNITED STATES COUNCIL FOR AUTOMOTIVE RESEARCH; PAUL JESCHKE, CHAIRMAN, ILLINOIS CORN GROWERS ASSOCIATION; AND CHET THOMPSON, PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, AMERICAN FUEL & PETROCHEMICAL </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. My name is Tim Columbus. I am from the law firm of Steptoe & Johnson. I appear today on behalf of our clients, the National Association of Convenience Stores and the Society of Independent Gasoline Marketers of America. These associations represent over 80 percent of retail fuel sales in the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Columbus">As a result of--as Mr. Tonko knows, my favorite term is ``the big stupid price signs''--that market is the most transparent and price competitive commodities market on the face of the earth.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Simply stated, retailers want to sell products in a legal way to people who want to buy them. They don't buy them because we sell them. We sell them because they want them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Because they do not manufacture the products they sell, they favor, as do all buyers, deep, diverse markets behind them from which they can obtain supplies. And in that context I should comment that the RFS has, in fact, diversified the market from which our members purchase product.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Columbus">As I told Chairman Shimkus and Ranking Member Tonko at their first roundtable on this issue, retailers seek peace in the valley. We believe that the concept that is being proposed today offers, perhaps, a path to achieve that objective.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Implementing a program in which all new cars would be required to run on higher octane fuels, fundamentally a performance standard, would have the following salutary effects, in our opinion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Number one, consumers would benefit from, A, higher mileage, and B, that the costs of fuels would be driven down based on the economic advantage of their component parts. Today the cheapest octane on earth is, in fact, ethanol. I believe this opens a substantial opportunity for ethanol and that that can, in fact, lower the cost of motor fuels overall.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Number two, the environment would benefit from decreased auto emissions. High-compression engines are more efficient, we get better mileage, and we spew less stuff into the air. It is a technical term, ``stuff.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Fuel marketers would benefit from a continued and evolving diversity in supply, which will drive down their costs and, therefore, the costs of their customers. I believe fuels' manufacturers would benefit from their increased ability to supply products which are marketed based on their economic efficiencies in relevant markets, rather than based on a formulaic approach.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Columbus">For retailer marketers in particular, the specific benefits of this approach, I think, are the following. The change in the product mix would occur over time. That results in, at least at the outset, minimal if any need to modify existing infrastructure. RON 95 is in the market today, and it is available at virtually every retail outlet in the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Columbus">By assuring an ever-increasing market for those new fuels, marketers will be in a position to make a decision to invest knowing that there is a guaranteed demand for the product that requires the investment and that they will be able to achieve an economic return.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Columbus">By opening the market to new fuels and properly allocating responsibility for compliance amongst manufacturers, marketers, and consumers, retailers will have the option of introducing new fuels to the market to meet consumers' demand for those fuels.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Columbus">In conclusion, NACS and SIGMA believe the concept being discussed today offers all the stakeholders in this debate the benefit of going forward based on a performance rather than a formulaic standard.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Columbus">I have been around some of you for a while. It has been my experience that, when manufacturers face a performance standard, it is the instance in which the great American competitive genius has produced the best economic results for the consumers and all of us who serve them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Columbus">We congratulate the subcommittee for holding this hearing. We urge you to move forward in an effort to alleviate the ongoing plague of industry squabbles and enhance the interests of fuel consumers in obtaining the most cost-effective fuels for their vehicles.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Columbus follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Columbus ">Thank you. I am happy to answer any questions that these comments or my statement may have raised for you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Columbus "> [GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The gentleman yields back time. The Chair thanks the gentleman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The Chair now recognizes Emily Skor, chief executive officer of Growth Energy.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF EMILY SKOR</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="EMILY SKOR"> Welcome. You are recognized for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Ms. Skor">Good morning, Chairman Shimkus, Ranking Member Tonko, and members of the subcommittee. Thank you for the opportunity to discuss the contributions of ethanol to high- octane fuels and future vehicle fuel economy standards.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Ms. Skor">My name is Emily Skor, and I am the CEO of Growth Energy, America's leading biofuels trade association, proudly representing 89 producers, 83 technology innovators in the supply chain, and tens of thousands of supporters across the country, including in Illinois. We work to bring consumers better choices at the pump, grow America's economy, and improve the environment for future generations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Ms. Skor">Ethanol is a homegrown biofuel that is now blended into 97 percent of standard gasoline, meeting more than 10 percent of our motor fuel needs. Ethanol-blended fuels have the highest octane of any available liquid alternative and allow for better-performing engines that deliver greater fuel efficiency.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Ms. Skor">American biofuels are ready to move America forward. With a stable policy and access to drivers, we can deliver low-carbon, low-cost, high-performing, sustainable vehicle fuel solutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Ms. Skor">Congress recognized the need for a more diverse and stable fuel supply and enacted the Renewable Fuel Standard to drive innovation and investment in renewable biofuels and open access to the marketplace. This energy policy is successfully driving advances in cellulosic ethanol, with plants operating at commercial scale, converting corn kernel fiber, corn stover, wood waste, and other biomass feedstocks into high-value energy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Ms. Skor">To continue our progress and fulfill congressional goals, U.S. consumers must have greater access to alternative fuel choices at the pump. Growth Energy has been working with fuel retailers to build the marketplace for fuel with higher blends of ethanol, such as E15 and E85, as well as install the infrastructure that can be used for high-octane midlevel ethanol blends, such as E30.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Ms. Skor">Today, low-cost higher blends are available at thousands of gas stations around the country. Consumers have already driven 4 billion miles on E15 and are ready to use this fuel nationwide year-round.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Ms. Skor">As fuel economy standards become increasingly stringent in the U.S. and worldwide, auto manufacturers are working toward more efficient engines that require high-octane fuels to operate effectively and lower greenhouse gases. Ethanol is a ready solution. With a natural 113 octane, ethanol has a lower carbon content than the gasoline components it replaces and provides increased engine efficiency to reduce greenhouse gas and criteria pollutant emissions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Ms. Skor">Growth Energy has been a leader in pushing for higher octane midlevel ethanol blends. We submitted the first proposal for a 100 RON E30 fuel nearly 7 years ago.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Ms. Skor">Robust research by national labs, automakers, and other scientific institutions has explored the myriad benefits of high-octane fuels and specifically a midlevel blend in the E20 to E30 range. When paired with various higher compression ratio engines, these fuels increase vehicle engine efficiency, lower tailpipe emissions, and increase use of renewable fuel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Ms. Skor">There have been recent discussions about moving to solely a 95 RON or 91 octane fuel standard. While we applaud any move to higher octane fuels, a 95 RON could easily be met with today's premium gasoline and there would be little to no incentive for oil refiners to move to higher biofuel blends. The past decade has shown oil companies will actively ignore economic incentives just to prevent market entry of higher ethanol blends.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Ms. Skor">We cannot assume that such a modest increase in octane will drive growth in demand for American-made biofuels and agriculture without the access to market provided by the RFS. Only by coupling a stable RFS to maintain market access with a significant boost in octane from a midlevel ethanol blend can consumers realize significant cost savings, increased engine efficiency, and substantial environmental benefits.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. Skor">Biofuels must be part of any long-term plan for engine efficiency and greenhouse gas reduction. However, any discussion of our future fuel mix cannot turn back the clock on the RFS. We cannot support a modest move in octane at the expense of one of the most successful domestic energy policies and the only legislated carbon reduction program.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Ms. Skor follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Ms. Skor ">Thank you for the opportunity to testify, and I am happy to answer any questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Ms. Skor "> [GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The Chair how recognizes Mr. Dan Nicholson, vice president, Global Propulsion Systems, General Motors, on behalf of the United States Council for Automotive Research.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF DAN NICHOLSON</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="DAN NICHOLSON"> You are recognized for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nicholson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">Chairman Walden, Chairman Shimkus, Ranking Member Pallone, and Ranking Member Tonko, and members of the committee, my name is Dan Nicholson, vice president of Global Propulsion Systems for General Motors Company. I am here today representing General Motors, a member company of the United States Council for Automotive Research, U.S. CAR. I appreciate the committee's invitation to appear before you to discuss the importance of increased octane in gasoline.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">As you know, the automotive industry is changing at an unprecedented pace. This requires all major mobility stakeholders to be better coordinated and to develop implementation strategies together.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">As the committee explores options, such as changes to U.S. fuel standards that may include higher octane gasoline, it is necessary that the industries involved in this opportunity work more closely together in order to ensure that consumers benefit and our industries remain strong.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">We believe increasing the minimum octane level in U.S. gasoline for new vehicles will be a win for all industries and, most importantly, consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">Today you will hear from many stakeholders involved in changing the liquid fuel market. This change requires the commitment of all parties. I would now like to take a few minutes to discuss the role of the automotive industry.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">Currently, many facets of the traditional automotive business are being disrupted. Innovative technologies are driving tremendous advancements in everything from safety and vehicle connectivity, to fuel efficiency and electrification.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">Additionally, societal trends, like urbanization and sustainability, are changing the way customers think about and interact with mobility. As GM's chairman and CEO, Mary Barra, likes to say, ``The auto industry will change more in the next 5 years than it has in the last 50 years.'' We believe this gives us opportunity to make cars cleaner, safer, smarter, more efficient, and more fun to drive than ever before.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">As part of this significant shift, the automotive industry has taken unprecedented steps to improve engine efficiency through downsized turbocharged engines, improved multispeed transmissions, and a host of eco-friendly improvements, all with the goal of meeting customer requirements while delivering improved efficiency.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">The global automotive market is growing, and multiple technologies and solutions will be needed to match demand. Octane is one of those solutions. We have an opportunity to play a large role in offering consumers the most affordable option for fuel economy improvement and greenhouse gas reduction.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">We believe a higher efficiency gasoline solution with a higher research octane number, or RON, is very important to achieving this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">U.S. CAR research shows that 95 RON makes sense from the viewpoints of both refiners and fuel retailers. As you may know, this is the same level of RON that Europe has used as their minimum level for many years. Without this new fuel, we will continue to endure the impacts of fuel variation and forego related available fuel economy improvement opportunities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Nicholson">Ultimately, policy leadership is key to bringing about fundamental change in the market. Your leadership is critical here. We need to work together to improve the fuel in the U.S. market to take advantage of engine designs that are more efficient and provide significant large-scale fuel economy improvements and corresponding reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. And we must do so in a way that makes sense for consumers, which means developing a favorable consumer model for fuel and coordinated retail introduction.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Nicholson follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Nicholson ">Thank you again for the opportunity to be here today and to discuss the advantages of high-octane fuels used in high- efficiency vehicles.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Nicholson "> [GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Thank you very much.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Now I would like to recognize Mr. Paul Jeschke, testifying on behalf of the Illinois Corn Growers Association.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF PAUL JESCHKE</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="PAUL JESCHKE"> We want to welcome you. You are recognized for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Jeschke</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Thank you, Chairman Shimkus, Ranking Member Tonko. Thank you for inviting me here to speak about what high- octane fuel can do for America's farmers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">As a corn farmer from the village of Mazon, Illinois, I never imagined that I would be sitting in this chamber in our Nation's Capital talking about corn-based higher octane fuels.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">A growing body of evidence shows that high-octane midlevel ethanol blends offer the most environmentally friendly and cost-effective route to increased vehicle efficiency and lower greenhouse gas emissions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">High-octane gasoline derived solely from hydrocarbons is dirtier and more costly. Today's premium fuels can cost 40 to 80 cents a gallon more than regular unleaded gasoline.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Consumers deserve an affordable high-octane choice at the pump. Ethanol is simply the most cost-effective octane additive available in the marketplace.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">A midlevel ethanol blend consists of 25 to 30 percent ethanol. Splash-blend that in today's regular gasoline blend stock and you would end up with an octane rating of 98 to 100 RON, higher than today's premium. This fuel would enable more efficient vehicles and lower greenhouse gas emissions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">High-octane midlevel ethanol blends mean lower costs for both refiners and consumers. These fuels could be made by splash-blending ethanol into existing regular gasoline blend stock with no change at the refinery. These blends would reduce upstream greenhouse gas emissions because ethanol is less carbon intensive, and it would improve air quality as ethanol displaces harmful air pollutants from aromatic hydrocarbons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Given our trend line gains in corn yields, I believe we can meet the future demand for corn-based ethanol on the land that we are farming now. Farmers are growing more corn, or more octane, per acre now than ever before.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">The growth of corn ethanol production has done more to bring profitability to corn farmers than any of the many Government support programs which I have experienced. And ethanol's development was financed to a large extent with farmer investment. This profitability allowed many young people to return to the farm, including my nephew, in my case.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">But domestic ethanol use has stagnated and our profitability is again collapsing. Since 2014, Illinois farm profit has been dismal. This projects a bleak future for all of us, but especially these younger farmers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">What can be done? The answer seems clear to me. As our vehicles of the future need higher octane, cleaner-burning fuel, we should look to higher blends of ethanol. Our Nation's fueling infrastructure can already accommodate midlevel ethanol blends, and with only minor investments the needed fueling infrastructure could be readily available nationwide, similar to that of diesel fuel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Unfortunately, the EPA regulations are stifling both fuel and engine innovations, preventing consumers from enjoying the performance benefits and fuel savings of midethanol blends. Until these barriers are addressed, it is simply not true that a minimum octane standard would provide the biofuel industry with the opportunity to expand its market share.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">For ethanol to be free to compete in the market on the basis of its value as an octane enhancer, the EPA's anticompetitive regulations must be corrected.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Some of these regulatory concerns are the same RVP standards for all fuels containing at least 10 percent ethanol, which may have happened yesterday: a new high-octane, midlevel ethanol alternative certification fuel, such as a 98 to 100 E25; a fuel economy equation that does not penalize ethanol blends; a technology-neutral fuel economy and GHG regulatory scheme that treats all alternative fuels alike to the extent that they reduce petroleum consumption and greenhouse gas emissions; an accurate lifecycle analysis of the greenhouse gas benefits of corn ethanol, like those that the USDA and the Department of Energy have already developed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">EPA could address these issues through regulation, without the need for new legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">In addition, automakers should warranty new vehicles for ethanol concentrations of up to 25 percent, similar as BMW has already done for some of their vehicles.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Removing these barriers would clear the road for high- octane, high-efficiency vehicles. More details on these points and other observations and suggestions are covered in the written testimony that I have submitted.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">I am proud of what we do on my family's farm. I am proud that our corn crop can have a part to play in the high-octane future that is heading our way if we are allowed to do so. America's corn farmers are ready to do our part to deliver.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Jeschke follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Jeschke ">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Jeschke "> [GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Thank you very much for joining us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">And now I would like to turn to Mr. Chet Thompson, president and CEO of the American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers.</paragraph>

<opening>STATEMENT OF CHET THOMPSON</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="CHET THOMPSON"> Sir, your full statement is in the record. You have 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Thank you, Chairman Shimkus, Chairman Walden, Ranking Member Tonko, members of the subcommittee. Thank you for the opportunity to bat cleanup this morning and provide the AFPM's views on this important subject of higher octane fuel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Thompson">As you mentioned, my name is Chet Thompson. I am the president and CEO of the American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers, AFPM. We believe we are uniquely qualified to weigh in on this topic as we represent the U.S. refining industry and supply virtually all of the gasoline used in the country today. So I will use my limited time to focus on a few aspects of my written testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Thompson">First, AFPM is absolutely intrigued by the possibilities and opportunities that could be afforded by a higher octane fuel. Such fuels, as you mentioned, Mr. Chairman, could be a solution to the RFS that works for all stakeholders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Again, also as you mentioned, today's hearing comes at a critical time for the U.S. fuel and automotive sectors. The auto industry faces enormous challenges to comply with CAFE while at the same time meeting consumer preferences. The refining industry is dealing with an inefficient and unworkable Renewable Fuel Standard that is only going to get worse with time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Fuel marketers in the biofuel industry don't have it easy either, to be sure. They are faced with constant uncertainty and never-ending debates about the RFS, making for a very challenging business environment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Again, these uncertainties will grow worse with every moment we move closer to 2022 when EPA takes over this program. But we believe there is a potential solution for all of this: higher octane fuel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Thompson">If done correctly--and by that I am going to get into what ``done correctly'' means in a minute--higher octane fuel has the potential to make life better for everyone at this table and in this room.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Over the last few years, we have been evaluating the benefits of various octane levels. Our detailed analysis show that a 95 RON performance standard could be an efficient and affordable option to reduce emissions and meet the needs of the auto sector.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Thompson">A 95 RON standard would help auto companies, as Mr. Nicholson said, comply with CAFE by meaningfully improving the efficiency of the internal combustion engine. By our estimates, 95 RON would reduce greenhouse gas emissions in this country by the equivalent of putting 720,000 EVs on the road each year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Thompson">So let me put that number in perspective. In 2016, 200,000 EVs were sold globally. So we are talking about tripling that year after year through 95 RON. And if you look at figure 3 on page 9 of my testimony, you can see that 95 RON is the lowest- cost fuel option for making these gains. Ninety-five RON is the lowest cost option for consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Thompson">So finally it also has the benefit, 95 RON, of being available and scalable nationwide on the timeline needed by the auto industry. No other octane level can make this claim, not a single one.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Thompson">So we believe a 95 RON would be good for the ethanol industry, as well. I am sure they appreciate me saying that. We would expect it to provide them with every bit as much ethanol demand as they get under the RFS, and likely more. This is true for a simple reason, because ethanol at the moment is a low- cost source of octane. So it follows that they would thrive under a high-octane performance standard, one done under the free market and not through Government mandate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Fuel marketers would benefit, as well, as Mr. Columbus said. A fuel-neutral 95 RON performance standard would provide marketers with optionality and flexibility. Importantly, this would translate to the benefit of consumers by creating a transparent and competitive market for all liquid fuels.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Finally, my members would certainly benefit, as well. Sunsetting the RFS and transitioning to a 95 RON performance standard would end mandates, reduce overall compliance burdens, and provide achievable regulatory targets.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Thompson">So such a standard would require enormous investments from my industry. Tens of billions of dollars would be needed. So we certainly don't take this hearing lightly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Thompson">We are, however, willing to entertain it for one simple reason: frankly, as a compromise solution to the RFS that we, again, believe could work for all stakeholders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Thompson">But for it to make sense to us, frankly, under any circumstances a 95 RON standard would have to include three elements. First, it would have to be accompanied by a sunset of the RFS. The refining industry simply can't comply with the burdens of the RFS at the same time making investments to bring 95 RON to market. Second, it would have to be implemented over a reasonable period of time. And third, it must include measures to prevent misfueling.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Thompson">As to the latter, we are certainly in a process now to evaluate all the obstacles that would be brought about by bringing a new fuel to market. We are working on that. These issues are real. But the good news is, through our analysis so far we don't think any of these obstacles are insurmountable.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Thompson">So in conclusion, AFPM believes that higher octane fuel has the potential to better harmonize our country's fuel and vehicle policies, and for that reason we believe it deserves further consideration and analysis.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Mr. Thompson follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Mr. Thompson ">We thank you, Mr. Chairman, for the opportunity to be here today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Thompson "> [GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Thank you very much. I appreciate everybody's testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">To my colleagues on the subcommittee, welcome to my world. I believe that we are closer than people think. And I want to encourage my colleagues to really help now dig into this issue specifically so we can address and work through some of these concerns.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Having said that, I would like to recognize myself 5 minutes for my first round of questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">For all you all--that is what we say in southern Illinois, ``all you all''--this hearing is more about the high-octane concept overall and less about debating the specifics, such as where that number should be set. So without advocating for a specific number, can each of you sketch out what you need in order for high-octane fuels to work for you and your member companies?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Tim. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Columbus">We believe there are a couple things that we would have to have. Number one, we would have to have a regulatory regime that guaranteed retailers who complied with warnings, signage standards, that if a motorist introduced the wrong fuel into his new vehicle the Environmental Protection Agency would not be holding the retailer accountable for that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Columbus">When we went from leaded to unleaded gasoline retailers were prosecuted by EPA if consumers put leaded gasoline in a vehicle meant for unleaded. That has got to change for us.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Number two, we would think it would be crucial that the one-pound waiver Reid vapor pressure requirements afforded E10 be extended to any blend of fuels that has an RVP equal to or less than E10.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Columbus"> And finally--and others can speak to this as well--I would hope that you could do something to accelerate the approval process for new gasolines. I think it took 3 years to do E15. If we are going to go to higher blends--and I anticipate that over time we would go to higher blends than just E10, E15--I think the market will end up demanding more than 95 RON. Ninety-five 95 RON is a floor for us, not a cap. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Ms. Skor. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Ms. Skor">Thank you. I would have to echo much of what Mr. Columbus said in that, yes, first and foremost, the ability to sell a legal fuel such as E15 year-round and any blends above 10 percent year-round is going to be absolutely paramount because you look at that today, and that is really the largest impediment to much further market adoption of E15.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. Skor">I would second that the approval process of new fuels has been very slow and cumbersome, so that, too, is something that you would want to see expedited, again in continuance of this quest for a free market and access to the consumer in the marketplace.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Ms. Skor"> And importantly, any discussion of high octane--and I appreciate how much ethanol is recognized as the cheapest octane source on the planet. Having said that, if you look at the last decade of market behavior and dynamics, refiners do walk away from that economic source of octane due to competition. And so we would like to see and we would need to see that there is a designation that that high-octane source is renewable fuels as the source of octane. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Mr. Nicholson. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nicholson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Nicholson"> We need one national standard for the fuel. That is important to us. And we would like to be part of making sure the specifications are correct and that it is interrelated with emissions criteria. But one national standard, I think, is what we are seeking. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Mr. Jeschke. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Jeschke</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Jeschke">Well, as a supplier of the raw materials for ethanol, corn farmers are ready to do their part. We have got piles of corn all over this country right now on the ground yet. That is how much of a surplus of that commodity we have. Those are being picked up now.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Jeschke"> But, again, the raw material that we are providing can easily be geared up. What we are growing naturally yields about 1 percent a year, and so I think we can do our part. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> Mr. Thompson. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Thompson"> We need the RFS to sunset. We cannot do both high-octane fuel and the RFS. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Great. Thanks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> For Growth and the corn growers, would you support any level of stringency that gives you at least as much ethanol that you currently use today? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Ms. Skor">So I think if the conversation is simply high- octane standards, that is a wonderful thing that we should be moving toward as a country. If the conversation is a high- octane standard coupled with some change to the RFS, that is a different conversation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Ms. Skor"> If you look at the market potential that is the congressional intent of the RFS, 90 percent of our market access is yet to come, and that is on the advanced side. So importantly, one of the things that we get that we have provided with the market access of the Renewable Fuel Standard is that innovation and that drive toward use of---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">My time is about ready to expire, and I want Mr. Jeschke to get a chance to answer. But you didn't answer the question on stringency.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> So, Mr. Jeschke. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Jeschke</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Jeschke"> We are wanting to grow the market. Again, I talked about the piles of corn we have. So we are wanting to grow our share of the fuel market ethanol production. We think it is good for farmers and good for the environment. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Great. Thank you very much.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> The Chair now recognizes the ranking member of the subcommittee, Mr. Tonko, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> Mr. Thompson, if the RFS is replaced with the high-octane standard, as you suggest, it is my understanding that there are other petrochemical-derived chemicals that could be blended into gasoline to achieve the octane rating of premium fuel. Is that correct? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Thompson"> Yes, that is correct. Gasoline is a blend, and there are lots of blends that have octane in it. But our analysis shows, if we went to a 95 RON standard, ethanol would continue to be the dominant source of octane. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> Right. OK. But some refineries might choose to meet the octane standard with an additive other than ethanol. Would that be an option in the absence of the RFS program's mandate or some other requirement to blend renewable fuel with gasoline? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Thompson"> Certainly that would be an option provided it can be done consistent with air quality and their local permitting, which absolutely our modeling shows that there would be no environmental detriment due to other sources of octane being used. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I would point out that, when Congress mandated a performance standard to increase the oxygenate content, the industry used MTBE to achieve this standard, and we ended up with a terrible drinking water pollution problem. So before we open the door to increased blending with other additives, I would like to know what risks might be involved in making that decision.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> Ms. Skor, the RFS program was intended to reduce petroleum use and to increase the use of renewable fuels. If renewable fuels are no longer specified and we replace the RFS with a high-octane standard set at 95 RON levels, what is the impact on the overall demand for renewable fuel? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Ms. Skor"> Well, there would be no impact on the overall demand. I mean, as has been stated by the other panelists, a 95 RON is a 91 premium fuel. It is currently sold on the marketplace, often with a 10 percent ethanol blend. So if we move to a national standard of 91 there would be little to no incentive to further use biofuels in our national transportation mix. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> So what might this mean for the development of advanced biofuels and for the transition to greater use of cellulosic biofuels? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Ms. Skor"> Well this would eviscerate really all of the innovation and investment that has taken place so far, if you look at advanced biofuels. Just a few years ago, when the RFS blending targets were put on hold, we as a Nation lost billions of investments in next-generation technology because of the lack of certainty that these fuels that I will say contribute 90-plus percent greenhouse gas reduction--the uncertainty that there would be no market for them in the U.S. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> As we have discussed, the Department of Energy, in collaboration with vehicle manufacturers, has been exploring the optimal combination of high-octane fuels with advanced high-compression engines, the Co-Optima study. My understanding is the octane levels they are working with are 95 or 96 octane or 100 RON, and that the source of octane is presumed to be renewable fuels at blends that are E25 to perhaps E30. Is that correct, Ms. Skor? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Ms. Skor"> Yes, that is correct. And that program is similar to a large body of work that is examining the sweet spot, if you will, in an E20 to an E30 blend where you are optimizing the cost savings for consumers coupled with that 90 percent greenhouse gas reduction that you are going to be getting--or excuse me, the greater greenhouse gas reduction--and the reduced tailpipe emissions. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> And, Mr. Columbus, you and I have discussed that, when it comes to fuels, there is one thing consumers care about above all else, and that is the price. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Columbus"> Yes, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> I imagine during the transition to a 95 RON fuel standard there will be some new vehicles that will require something similar to today's premium fuel and many existing vehicles which continue to opt for the cheapest option. How do you envision consumer acceptance of a requirement to buy more expensive fuel? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Well, first of all, let's talk about premium gasoline prices today as opposed to regular-grade gasoline. It is a specialty product, Mr. Tonko. It is like going someplace and trying to get ethanol-free gasoline. People pay a premium for it because there is very narrow demand for it today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Having said that, I envision that a 95 RON, if it is coupled with a waiver of the one-pound waiver for higher blends of ethanol, you are going to see prices come down on that product. Why? Because ethanol is, in fact, the cheapest product.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Columbus">Something I want you to always remember, Mr. Thompson's members are important to us, but they are not the only source of blend stocks on the face of the earth. If, in fact, there are cheaper forms of blend stock, my clients will do so. Many of them today have introduced E15. Why? Because it is cheaper in the retail market because of the ethanol component. So that ability to use increased amounts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Columbus"> There is, however, a cap on that, and that is you have to have an infrastructure that will handle it, sir. And today EPA's rules say if it is not certified to hold a higher blend than E10, not warranted, and a retailer cannot affirmatively demonstrate that that equipment is compatible, and it goes back to the MTBE stuff, he has violated the Resource Conservation Recovery Act. So prices will come down because component prices will come down. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The gentleman's time has expired.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> The Chair now recognizes the chairman of the full committee, Mr. Walden. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Walden">Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. And I very much appreciate your willingness to chair this subcommittee and take on this issue. I know how much fun it must be for you being conflicted with all these things. But you are doing a great job, and we appreciate it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Walden"> To everybody on the panel, in one capacity or another you are all involved in the Renewable Fuel Standard or you wouldn't be before us today. Can I get you all to agree that a high- octane fuel standard, if done right, could be an improvement over the status quo? And that is a pretty easy yes or no. Start at that end. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Columbus"> Yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Ms. Skor"> A high-octane standard, provided that you couple that with the market access and the drive toward growth that you get with a Renewable Fuel Standard. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Walden"> So I just want to make sure we are answering the same question. Can you agree that a high-octane fuel standard, if done correctly, could be an improvement over the status quo, yes or no? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Ms. Skor"> Possibly. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Walden"> OK. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nicholson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Mr. Nicholson"> Absolutely, yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Mr. Walden"> Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Jeschke</speaker> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Mr. Jeschke"> I will take a chance and say yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Mr. Walden"> OK. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Mr. Thompson"> Yes, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Mr. Walden">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Mr. Walden"> Mr. Columbus, the gas station is where the fuel policy either succeeds or fails, because that is the interface with the consumer, and you have done a good job of representing the consumers here. On balance, do you see a high-octane fuel standard potentially working for the benefit of the consumer? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Columbus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="69" speaker="Mr. Columbus"> I do, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="70" speaker="Mr. Walden">All right.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="71" speaker="Mr. Walden"> Ms. Skor, one of the exciting things about the high-octane fuel standard--well, our version of it--is that it allows us to take full advantage of ethanol's properties as an octane enhancer. Would you agree that such a policy could lead to a more advantageous use of ethanol? </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Skor</speaker> <paragraph paraId="72" speaker="Ms. Skor"> I think the 95 RON policy discussed right now will not necessarily lead to a more advantageous use of biofuel for consumers. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="73" speaker="Mr. Walden">You know, I was on this committee--there are a few of us left that were in '05, '06, '07. The energy situation we faced then is much different than it is today. That was an era of scarcity. We were watching what was going on in Brazil with ethanol. I mean, it was a different world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="74" speaker="Mr. Walden">And I supported the RFS then, and I have worked on it, and I have got a little bit of that. And I think there is a difference, by the way, between corn ethanol and the advance in cellulosic, and you mentioned that in your comments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="75" speaker="Mr. Walden">I was in the radio business for 21 years. I would have loved to have had a mandate that somebody has to buy my inventory. I am just saying. I grew up on a farm, I get it. I am an orchardist.
